word.entryDescription: to move forward by repeatedly putting one foot in front of the other
word.entryExample: I walk to school, I don't take the bus.

word.entryDescription: to take a dog for a walk for exercise
word.entryExample: I get up at seven, have a shower, get dressed and walk the dog.

word.entryDescription: the vertical flat surface at the side of a room
word.entryExample: The walls in my bedroom are white.

word.entryDescription: a small case in which you keep your money, cards and important documents
word.entryExample: Whose wallet is this? It's Harry's.

word.entryDescription: a large-scale armed conflict between countries or groups
word.entryExample: When Florence returned to England after the war she had become famous.

word.entryDescription: a big cupboard in which you hang clothes
word.entryExample: In my bedroom I've got a wardrobe and a chest of drawers where I keep my clothes and sports gear.

word.entryDescription: having a pleasant temperature but not hot
word.entryExample: It's very warm today, so let's go for a walk.

word.entryDescription: to make something/someone warm or warmer
word.entryExample: When the baby wakes up I need to warm up some milk in the microwave for him.

word.entryDescription: to tell someone that something bad or dangerous is present or possible
word.entryExample: The detectives will need to warn people about the man – he could be dangerous.

word.entryDescription: a statement or sign which tells you that something bad is possible or present
word.entryExample: He started to shoot without any warning.

word.entryDescription: to clean something wth soap and water
word.entryExample: I need to wash my clothes, they're dirty.

word.entryDescription: to wash the dishes by hand
word.entryExample: Around seven, I make dinner and wash up.

word.entryDescription: a machine you use to wash clothes, sheets, towels, etc
word.entryExample: When the washing machine finishes, she needs to put the clothes in the tumble dryer.

word.entryDescription: unwanted materials or substances that are left after something has been used
word.entryExample: Put the recycling and food waste out for collection tonight.

word.entryDescription: to use something badly or use too much of something
word.entryExample: Don't waste the sandwiches your mother made for you.

word.entryDescription: to look at and enjoy something like television or sport
word.entryExample: I watch TV in the evenings.

word.entryDescription: a clear liquid with no colour or taste that you need to drink
word.entryExample: Can I have a glass of water?

word.entryDescription: a building where energy is produced by water turning a large wheel
word.entryExample: The villagers have bought an old water mill.

word.entryDescription: large container for storing water
word.entryExample: This bath is connected to a water tank outside.

word.entryDescription: the gas form of water
word.entryExample: Some of the most important greenhouse gases are water vapour, carbon dioxide, methane and ozone.

word.entryDescription: a place where a river or stream drops suddenly from higher to lower ground
word.entryExample: Next to the mountain there is a beautiful waterfall.

word.entryDescription: a very big round fruit with a thick green skin and juicy pink flesh
word.entryExample: I love to eat watermelon in the summer.

word.entryDescription: not allowing water to go through
word.entryExample: Take your waterproof jacket when we go camping.

word.entryDescription: an area of moving water that is at a higher level than the main surface of a sea, ocean, etc.
word.entryExample: Through the open windows you can hear the waves crashing against the rock beneath the house.

word.entryDescription: direction or route
word.entryExample: Excuse me, do you know the way to Buckingham Palace?

word.entryDescription: not strong
word.entryExample: I'm not very strong, I'm weak.

word.entryDescription: a lot of money or things of value that are possessed
word.entryExample: Is wealth the most important thing in your life?

word.entryDescription: an object or device used to cause harm or damage, or used in fighting
word.entryExample: Many tribal males wear weapons even if they don't hunt or fight.

word.entryDescription: to have clothes on your body
word.entryExample: What does she usually wear?

word.entryDescription: the conditions that exist in the air like the temperature, rain, snow, sun, etc
word.entryExample: We can't leave now, because the weather is very windy.

word.entryDescription: a description of what the weather is expected to be like in the future
word.entryExample: What's the weather forecast for this afternoon?

word.entryDescription: crossing fibres or threads over and under each other to make fabric
word.entryExample: The creation of the Panama hats consists of two main processes – weaving and blocking.

word.entryDescription: a person who designs websites
word.entryExample: A web designer is responsible for the layout and the general design of the website.

word.entryDescription: a video camera that is connected to a computer and that broadcasts what it is filming on a website or on another computer
word.entryExample: I use my webcam a lot as I like to see my friends when I am video conferencing and they can see me too.

word.entryDescription: a set of pages on the internet that has been set up by a person or organisation
word.entryExample: Check out our website for a detailed map and directions.

word.entryDescription: a ceremony at which people get married
word.entryExample: Thank you very much for inviting us to your wedding celebration.

word.entryDescription: Saturday and Sunday
word.entryExample: I often go swimming at the weekend.

word.entryDescription: how heavy something/somebody is
word.entryExample: The doctor said I should do a sport to get fit and lose weight.

word.entryDescription: lifting weights as a form of exercise
word.entryExample: Have you ever done any weight training?

word.entryDescription: strange; odd
word.entryExample: Picasso's paintings of faces often have weird facial configurations.

word.entryDescription: to greet someone in a polite and friendly way in a specific place
word.entryExample: Welcome to my new house, come in!

word.entryDescription: in a good way
word.entryExample: I can speak English very well.

word.entryDescription: not naughty
word.entryExample: If you want to give me a really nice present, be well-behaved and quiet for five minutes. OK?

word.entryDescription: the state of feeling comfortable, healthy and happy
word.entryExample: Pets are a wonderful way to improve our well-being.

word.entryDescription: wearing attractive fashionable clothes
word.entryExample: He opened the the door and saw an attractive, well-dressed young woman.

word.entryDescription: well protected with a material that prevents heat, sound, etc. from passing through
word.entryExample: Passive houses are building developments which are well-insulated, almost air-tight to minimise energy loss, thanks to triple-glazed windows.

word.entryDescription: known by a lot of people
word.entryExample: There aren't any really well-known actors in this film, but the filming looks great.

word.entryDescription: made to a good or high standard; well constructed
word.entryExample: The critics said this film was really well-made and had a good storyline.

word.entryDescription: intending to be helpful, but often not succeeding
word.entryExample: We even had a dog, once, that had been run over and was brought in by a well-meaning passer-by!

word.entryDescription: past simple of 'go' – to move to or towards another place
word.entryExample: We also went to Cape Town and climbed up Table Mountain.
